tetra.logic

Enum Tetromino

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.lang.Enum<Tetromino>
      • tetra.logic.Tetromino
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable, Comparable<Tetromino>

    public enum Tetromino
extends Enum<Tetromino>
    A geometric shape composed of 4 blocks. The definition of a tetromino specifies that the blocks must connected orthogonally, allowing for 7 distinct shapes. This class defines these shapes on a 4x4 grid where each cell is either occupied or unoccupied.

    It is the responsibility of this class to describe how these shapes rotate. According to the rules of the game, each shape has 4 available orientations attained by 90 degree rotations. The initial orientation is always up, chosen such that the tetromino spawns horizontally with its flat side pointed down.

    From a conceptual point of view, it would be natural to implement this class as an array of blocks. The implementation of this class, however, takes a more economic approach. The shapes are defined as 16 bit integers, described in more detail in this source. It turns out, that this representation is not only compact but also quite convenient if one knows how to read hexadecimals.

      • isOccupied

        public boolean isOccupied(Direction orientation,
                          int x,
                          int y)
        Returns true if there's a block in the specified (x, y) position; false otherwise. The result depends on the specified orientation, since the configuration of blocks is different for each orientation. If the x- or y-coordinate is out of range, returns false.
        Parameters:
        orientation - the orientation to inspect. The configuration of blocks is different for each orientation.
        x - x-coordinate of the position to inspect
        y - y-coordinate of the position to inspect
        Returns:
        true if there's a block in the specified position, false otherwise

      • getBlock

        public Block getBlock(Direction orientation,
                      int x,
                      int y)
        Returns the block in the specified (x, y) position, or null if the position is empty. The result depends on the specified orientation, since the configuration of blocks is different for each orientation. If the x- or y-coordinate is out of range, returns null.
        Parameters:
        orientation - the orientation to inspect. The configuration of blocks is different for each orientation.
        x - x-coordinate of the element to return
        y - y-coordinate of the element to return
        Returns:
        the block at the specified position, or null if the position is empty
